Project Number: 37549 
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R–CDTA) 
January 2010 
 
 
 
 
Support for South Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In line with the key operational objectives1 of the Regional Cooperation Strategy and 
Program for South Asia (2006–2008),2 the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported 
regional cooperation through the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC),3 
interregional cooperation through the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and 
Economic  Cooperation  (BIMSTEC),4 and  subregional  cooperation  through  the  South  Asia 
Subregional Economic Cooperation Program.5  
 
2.  The  High  Level  Forum  on  Emerging  Vision  for  Shared  Prosperity:  South  Asia  and 
Beyond (the forum) was held in ADB on 16–17 April 2009 to discuss country and regional 
visions and priorities and to deliberate on possible approaches to, and an operational framework 
for,  supporting  regional  cooperation.  Secretaries  and  senior  officials  from  the  ministries  of 
finance and foreign affairs of South Asian countries and their neighbors, as well as senior 
officials from the SAARC Secretariat, participated in the forum. The forum recognized the 
importance of a flexible, pragmatic, multi-track approach to advancing regional cooperation in 
South Asia with a focus on fast-tracking the implementation of tangible regional investment 
projects. The forum identified options through which ADB could support regional cooperation in 
South Asia and beyond, including (i) regional and interregional projects, (ii) subregional projects 
involving more than two countries, and (iii) bilateral projects.  
 
3.  Following  the  forum,  ADB  held  consultations  with  the  governments  of  South  Asian 
countries to discuss (i) the process and operational framework for developing and implementing 
regional and subregional projects, (ii) potential priority regional projects, and (iii) the scope of 
this regional technical assistance (TA). During these meetings, governments expressed general 
support for the TA.6   
 
4.  As suggested by the forum, the TA will adopt a flexible approach that can support 
regional, interregional, subregional, and bilateral projects in which South Asian countries and 
their neighbors participate. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.7  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  South Asia has posted strong economic growth in recent years and increased its share 
of world output from 4.5% in 1998 to 6% in 2008.8 However, South Asia is not only the region 
with the largest number of people living below the poverty line, it is also the least integrated 
region in Asia, with an intra-regional trade share in 2008 of only 5.5%, compared to 27.1%

REG). 
5  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation III. Manila (TA 6297-REG).

beyond.

2   
recorded by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.9 Further, recent uncertainties caused 
by various shocks including climate change, the spike in food prices, volatile energy prices, and 
the global economic crisis have challenged the growth potential of South Asia and adversely 
affected the lives of the region's poor. However, the recent shocks and changes in the political 
landscape provide a window of opportunity for countries in South Asia to renew their efforts to 
deepen regional cooperation to meet these challenges. Increased regional cooperation in South 
Asia and beyond, particularly increased regional connectivity, would allow for inclusive growth 
by  providing  increased  access  to  markets,  goods,  and  services  across  borders.  Regional 
cooperation can mobilize private investments, counter the impact of declining financial flows, 
and significantly reduce the share of the population living below the poverty line.  
 
6.  Regional cooperation has recently gained momentum in South Asia. However, while 
regional cooperation initiatives have successfully identified potential regional projects in key 
sectors  such  as  transport  and  trade  facilitation,  energy,  tourism,  and  information  and 
communication technology, the implementation of tangible regional projects has been limited. 
There is growing recognition of the need to realign regional projects with national programs as 
countries determine national priorities with greater focus and prioritize and implement regional 
projects.  
 
7.  Discussing the benefits of regional cooperation and effectively disseminating the findings 
of regional studies can help increase official and public awareness and support for regional 
cooperation initiatives in South Asia. Knowledge management can effectively spur development 
partner and private sector interest and involvement in contributing more significantly toward 
funding regional projects. 
 
8.  ADB-supported regional cooperation initiatives in South Asia have (i) identified priority 
regional  investments,  including  a  number  of  subregional  pilot  projects  to  improve  regional 
connectivity (through the SAARC Regional Multimodal Transport Study); (ii) proposed a policy 
framework for BIMSTEC transport and logistics, strategies, and an implementing mechanism to 
enhance  transport  infrastructure,  improve  logistics,  and  lower  transport  costs  (BIMSTEC 
Transport  Infrastructure  and  Logistics  Study);  and  (iii)  identified  subregional  projects  in 
information and communication technology, transport and trade facilitation, and tourism  through 
the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Program. Over and above these regional 
initiatives, countries have, through country programming, identified and implemented national 
projects that have strong regional potential. Hence, a rich pool of potential regional investment 
projects already exists that, once implemented, can bring enormous benefits to communities 
and countries in South Asia.   
 
9.  In line with ADB's commitment of allocating at least 30% of its operations to regional 
cooperation by 2020 (under ADB's Strategy 202010), this TA will support participating countries 
and regional organizations11 in further identifying, prioritizing, and preparing regional projects 
and national projects with regional implications, with the aim of promoting regional economic 
cooperation  and  economic  activity  among  South  Asian  countries.  The  TA  will  fully  utilize 
experiences and lessons from subregional initiatives and other regional cooperation initiatives 
and activities supported by ADB. Previous experience with subregional projects in South Asia 
shows that undertaking cross-border and multilateral agreements consumes time and needs to 
                                                 
9  Source: ADB Asia Regional Integration Center’s Integration Indicators Database. Available: www.aric.adb.org. 
10 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
11 Such as SAARC and BIMSTEC.

3
involve various stakeholders. This TA will involve key ministries, including ministries of finance 
and  foreign  affairs,  as  well  as  other  stakeholders,  at  early  stages  to  ensure  the  smooth 
endorsement and implementation of regional projects and agreements. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA is expected to enhance regional economic cooperation in South Asia. This will 
be gauged by increases in the movement of goods, services, information, and people in South 
Asia. The envisaged outcome is agreed regional cooperation activities and projects.  
 
11.  The TA will focus on (i) assisting participating countries in identifying and preparing 
regional projects12 and national projects with regional implications, (ii) preparing studies and 
papers to support the formation of a regional cooperation agenda, (iii) providing a venue for 
regional  dialogue,  and  (iv)  developing  regional  capacity  in  formulating  and  implementing 
regional projects and activities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have four components: (i) preparation of regional projects, (ii) awareness 
building, (iii) capacity development, and (iv) technical and logistical support.  The TA is designed 
to  be  flexible  in  order  to  support  regional  projects  agreed  among  participating  countries, 
including  projects  identified  under  the  SAARC  and  BIMSTEC  frameworks  and  ongoing 
subregional initiatives, bilateral projects with regional implications, and national projects with 
regional implications, which will serve as building blocks to wider regional cooperation in South 
Asia. The TA is also flexible in supporting the participation of South Asian countries13  and its 
neighbors in regional projects and activities.  
 
13.  Preparation of regional projects. Regional technical meetings and workshops will be 
organized to assist participating countries in prioritizing and preparing regional projects and 
national projects with regional implications in the priority sectors of transport, energy, and trade 
facilitation, based on the rich pool of potential regional investment projects identified earlier. 
These meetings can be used to discuss and develop sector road maps as needed. The TA will 
support  high-level  forums  of  senior  government  officials  to  be  held  annually  to  facilitate 
discussions on strategic directions and to obtain the endorsement of priority regional projects.  
 
14.  Studies and papers on selected regional cooperation topics will be prepared, with a 
focus on prefeasibility studies for priority projects. These studies will provide technical and 
policy advisory inputs to, and support the formulation of, South Asia's regional cooperation 
agenda.  The  studies  and  papers  will  be  designed  in  close  coordination  with  participating 
countries, regional institutions, think tanks, and other stakeholders.  
 
15.  Awareness building. Awareness building activities such as regional conferences and 
forums for various stakeholders and policy makers will be organized to provide venues for 
regional dialogue and information exchange. Selected regional studies can be presented and 
discussed in these conferences. These activities can help generate wider support for regional 
cooperation in South Asia.  
                                                 
12 Including regional, intraregional, and subregional projects.  
13 South Asian countries are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

4   
 
16.  Capacity development. The TA will support capacity development programs that will be 
designed  in  close  coordination  with  participating  countries,  key  stakeholders,  and  regional 
institutions. Capacity development programs aim to enhance country and regional capacity to 
effectively  formulate  and  implement  regional  projects  and  activities  and  will  be  based  on 
successful training modules of other regional cooperation initiatives. A mix of case studies, 
experience sharing, on-site visits, and lectures can be used in capacity development. Other 
stakeholders can be invited to participate in training as appropriate.  
 
17.  Technical and logistical support. Technical and logistical support will be provided in 
ADB headquarters and selected resident missions to support the implementation of this TA, 
including the organization of regional meetings and forums and the facilitation of coordination 
among  participating  countries.  The  regional  cooperation  advisor  will  prepare  semiannual 
progress reports to be distributed to participating countries and provide regular updates on the 
status of TA implementation.  
 
18.  Given the multi-country nature of the TA and the complexities of cross-border projects, it 
is important to involve key stakeholders, including ministries of finance and foreign affairs and 
other relevant line agencies, in all stages of the TA implementation. As such, promoting and 
supporting dialogue with key policy makers from all participating governments and enhancing 
stakeholders’  awareness  of  the  benefits  of  regional  cooperation  are  crucial  to  generating 
support for regional cooperation in South Asia as a whole and for this TA in particular. The TA 
will encourage and facilitate private sector participation as appropriate. The TA is flexible in 
supporting the participation of South Asian countries and its neighbors in regional projects and 
activities and will follow SAARC guidelines of engagement where applicable. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA cost is estimated at $1.5 million and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV). The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months from January 2010 to December 2012.  
ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  South  Asia  Country  Coordination  and  Regional 
Cooperation Division will be responsible for TA implementation. An ADB TA team will comprise 
staff of the South Asia Country Coordination and Regional Cooperation Division and other 
divisions, resident missions, and consultants as appropriate. The ADB TA team will closely 
coordinate with participating countries and other departments in ADB, including the Central and 
West Asia Department, Southeast Asia Department, Office of Regional Economic Integration, 
and Regional and Sustainable Development Department. Designated focal persons in relevant 
divisions  of  the  ADB  South  Asia  Department  will  assist  in  implementing  activities  and/or 
programs. Disbursements under the TA will be conducted in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement  Handbook.14 Equipment  such  as  computers  and  software  will  be 
purchased in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Equipment will be turned over to ADB upon completion of the TA.  
 
                                                 
14 ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

5
21.  A total of 126 person-months of consultancy services will be engaged for this TA, 
including  108  person-months  of  national  consultancy.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  on  an 
individual basis in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
22.  The components for the preparation of regional projects and capacity development will 
require  18  person-months  of  international  consultancy  provided  by  thematic  experts  and 
capacity development specialists. Thematic experts will provide advisory and technical inputs on 
sector and thematic studies supported by the TA. Capacity development specialists will be 
responsible for designing and conducting capacity development programs. These programs will 
be designed in close consultation with participating countries.  
 
23.  The technical and logistical support component will be undertaken by ADB. The services 
of three national consultants based in ADB headquarters will be required for 90 person-months. 
These consultants will be a (i) regional cooperation advisor, (ii) regional cooperation specialist, 
and (iii) program analyst and/or regional cooperation expert. They will provide technical and 
logistical inputs and assist the ADB TA team in coordinating with participating countries and in 
organizing TA activities. In-country regional cooperation specialist(s) (national consultant[s]) will 
be engaged in resident mission(s) for a total of 18 person-months.  
 
24.  The progress of TA implementation will be monitored through regular progress reports, 
reports  and  updates  during  high-level  forums,  and  regular  country  consultation  meetings, 
among other means. A TA completion report will evaluate TA achievement. Good practices and 
lessons will be disseminated through the meetings, and progress reports will be circulated to 
selected stakeholders.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Support for South Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Under  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  Support  for  South  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation, international and national consultants will be recruited to (i) prepare studies and 
papers on regional cooperation, focusing primarily on prefeasibility studies for priority projects; 
(ii) implement capacity development programs for policy makers and other stakeholders; and (iii) 
provide  technical  and  logistical  support  for  implementing  the  TA.  All  will  be  engaged  as 
individual consultants.  
 
2.  The TA will engage international consultants as thematic experts to conduct sector and 
thematic  studies  and  as  capacity  development  specialists  to  undertake  the  capacity 
development component of the TA. A regional cooperation advisor, a regional cooperation 
specialist, and a program analyst and/or regional cooperation expert will be based in Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) headquarters and assist in implementing the TA. In-country regional 
cooperation specialist(s) based in resident mission(s) will be engaged to provide support and 
advice on regional and country-specific issues.  
 
A.  Studies and Capacity Development 
 
1.  Thematic Experts (international, 12 person-months) 
3.  International  consultants  will  be  recruited  for  sector  studies,  thematic  studies,  and 
prefeasibility  studies,  as  appropriate.  The  consultants  may  be  asked  to  work  with  other 
international  and  national  consultants  as  appropriate.  The  consultants  will  have  extensive 
experience  in  South  Asia  in  transport,  energy,  trade,  and/or  other  priority  sectors.  The 
consultants  will  be  engaged,  as  required,  to  provide  advisory  and  technical  services.  The 
thematic experts are expected to 
(i)  undertake extensive consultations with officials, private sector representatives, 
and other stakeholders to assess cooperation issues and opportunities in their 
sector; 
(ii)  analyze and prepare a paper on regional cooperation for the sector, including 
recommendations for projects; 
(iii)  conduct prefeasibility studies for prioritized projects; 
(iv)  revise and finalize completed sector reports based on reviews and comments 
from participating countries and ADB; 
(v)  organize and facilitate consultations and participatory meetings; 
(vi)  participate in meetings as approved; and 
(vii)  perform other tasks as necessary. 
 
2.  Capacity Development Specialists (international, 6 person-months) 
4.  International  consultants  with  expertise  in  capacity  development  and  extensive 
knowledge of regional cooperation issues in South Asia will be engaged to develop the capacity 
of  policy  makers  and  other  stakeholders  who  will  be  identified  in  close  consultations  with 
participating  countries.  They  may  be  asked  to  work  with  other  international  and  national 
consultants as appropriate. 
 
5.  The main tasks of the international consultants will include, but will not be limited to, the 
following:  
(i)  assess capacity building requirements;

including  venue  and  travel  arrangements,  disbursements  of  per  diem  to

(iii)  strengthen the knowledge-management system of the ADB South Asia regional

(iv)  compile all final prints and electronic version of pertinent reports, speeches, and

4.  In-Country Regional Cooperation Specialist(s) (national, 18 person-months) 
9.  Nationally recruited consultant(s) based in resident mission(s) will  
(i)  assist  ADB  in  TA  implementation  by  liaising  and  coordinating  with  the 
government and coordinating with the regional cooperation and integration team 
and other resident missions and sector experts to ensure the smooth flow of 
documents  and  communications  among  all  stakeholders  involved  in  TA 
implementation; 
(ii)  establish  and  maintain,  through  regular  contact  and  consultation,  working 
relationships  with  the  key  government  agencies  responsible  for  regional 
cooperation; 
(iii)  help prepare conferences, workshops, seminars, and meetings under the TA, as 
well as assist in preparing meeting documents; 
(iv)  prepare TA documents and papers, including progress reports as required; 
(v)  manage the database on TA implementation; 
(vi)  participate in ADB missions, conferences, workshops, and meetings as required; 
(vii)  carry out specified regional studies; and 
(viii)  carry out tasks related to regional cooperation as required.
